article_title: John Diaz: Court’s next big ruling could shake up politics
article_text:
John Diaz: Court’s next big ruling could shake up politics

Photo: Liz Hafalia, The Chronicle Senate President pro Tempore Kevin de León visits the Chronicle in...

As dramatic and consequential as last week was, with rulings on Obamacare and marriage equality, the U.S. Supreme Court is not quite finished. On Monday, the high court is expected to issue its ruling in an Arizona case that could detonate one of California’s most significant political reforms.

article_metadata.sailthru.author: By John Diaz
article_metadata.description: On Monday, the high court is expected to issue its ruling in an Arizona case that could detonate one of California’s most significant political reforms.  At issue is whether a state’s voters have the authority to empower a citizens commission — rather than state legislators — to draw congressional boundaries.  Arizona’s 2000 voter initiative set up a bipartisan commission to handle the decennial redistricting process.  Republicans who control the Arizona Legislature are challenging that system in the case that has reached the U.S. Supreme Court.  The Arizona Republicans’ argument is based on a very narrow reading of Article 1, Section 4 of the Constitution that gives state legislature the authority to determine the “times, places and manner” of federal elections.  Defenders of the independent commission maintained that legislatures should be defined more broadly to include the legislative process — including the ability of citizens to enact laws at the ballot box.  While it’s always risky to presume the justices’ ultimate decisions by their questions during oral arguments, the direction of the March hearing clearly was not favorable to the independent commission.  The court’s conservatives — along with Justice Anthony Kennedy, a potential swing vote — expressed skepticism at the notion that the framers intended to define legislature so broadly as to include voter initiatives.  While Republicans hold the reins in Phoenix, Democrats have a firm grip on both houses of the Legislature in Sacramento.  In California, voters similarly set up independent commissions to draw the boundaries for state legislative seats (Prop. 11, 2008) and congressional seats (Prop. 20, 2010).  A longtime observer of politics might wonder if those hearings might be used to provide political cover for the ruling Democrats to tinker with — or even overhaul — the boundaries.  When politicians draw the lines, it becomes mostly the art of protecting incumbents and advancing party interests — two elements that were expressly prohibited by the reform initiative.  [...] de León insisted that skeptics who think “we’re all pining and foaming at the mouth” to jump back into redistricting are mistaken.  If the Supreme Court rules against citizen redistricting commissions, then California’s legislative leaders should allow its independently drawn lines to stay in place until new boundaries are required after the 2020 census.  The U.S. Constitution’s elections clause gives Congress the authority “at any time” to “make or alter” the rules.  In California, lawmakers could appoint a citizens commission to draw the lines — keeping the fair-play criteria in the 2010 initiative — subject to ratification by the Legislature.  To take the responsibility for drawing boundaries for state Senate and Assembly out of the hands of legislators.  To invalidate a 2000 ballot initiative that created a bipartisan commission to draw congressional boundaries.  The GOP legislators argued that Article 1, Section 4 of the U.S. Constitution empowers each state legislature to decide the “times, places and manner” of elections for federal seats.
